pageContext.claim: “You remember those [DACA and wall] discussions. But where it really ended was when the judge ruled against, and it was -- I said, as soon as that happened -- because that was a shocking decision. It was shocking to the Democrats, and it was more shocking to the Republicans. … That's what broke up the DACA deal.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump backed away from this deal. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-N.Y.) met with Trump in early September 2017 and then announced they had a tentative deal that extended DACA but did not fund the border wall, although they did agree to include some form of border security measures. Trump took a beating from his right-wing supporters after that announcement, and days later tweeted that there was no deal with Pelosi and Schumer. No judge had ruled to uphold DACA in the interim. A federal judge ruled to uphold DACA in April 2018, roughly six months after Trump's meeting with Pelosi and Schumer.
